title: What technology trends will put call centers out of business? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m going to disagree with Mark Toole’s answer here (and I often don’t) for reasons of generalization. We’re a helpdesk, live chat, and customer messaging platform and have integrations with VOIP platforms like Aircall, RingCentral, JustCall, and many others soon. Over the past year, we’ve placed higher priority on integrating call center software due to rising demand across our user base. The reason for this high demand is fueled by the growth of B2C eCommerce and DNVBs. eCommerce companies both small, medium, and large are jumping on board implementing a call center to increase the reputation and trustworthiness of their business. Call center software can be implemented in a variety of ways now that actually tie into the idea of conversational commerce. There doesn’t need to necessarily hav PBX or IVR just because it’s a call center. Modern call centers can support integrations like direct logging of customer data into a helpdesk (like Re:amaze via RingCentral), data tracking, in-app call recordings, that can actually boost customer satisfaction. If there’s one thing that might kill off call centers, it’s chatbots. But from where I stand, customers still like calling just for a peace of mind and to see if a business is large enough to actually have support personnel for phone calls.

Thanks for A2A, Ashton! Honestly, I don’t think call centers will be ever put out of business. Chatbots may sound like a threat, but they’re still in their infant stage and they won’t replace contacting a real person. Of course, there are many communications channels - email, instant messengers, social media, etc. but still, the majority of customers prefer to call a real sales rep to solve their issue.  Nevertheless, tech trends have been changing the way call centers operate and they will likely shape their future. Here are a few trends to give you the idea: Cloud. The call center doesn’t have to be a huge and costly project. With a cloud-based solution, such as CloudTalk, it’s possible to set it up and integrate within a few clicks.IVR. An interactive voice response system helps to automate the process by routing the call to the right agent or providing simple information like an address or working hours.Emotion recognition. Some modern call center solutions, such as already mentioned CloudTalk, offer emotion recognitions thanks to which agents can use scripts that work better with furious or confused customers.I hope it helped!

Technology trends are sexy. But how about…  The fact that people HATE phone calls. The last phone call I actually answered was over 2 weeks ago. From my wife. And it lasted less than 1 minute. And I actually LIKE her! Calling a business for any kind of customer service issue is fucking MISERABLE. Phone rings half a time and then INSANELY LOUD BEEP IN YOUR EAR. Silly music Spanish talking. Press 47 for English. Silly voice recording menu that pretends to be a person and makes you talk back to it. I”M SORRY I DON’T UNDERSTAND Eventually you get some overworked script reading NPC who asks you a bunch of pointless “verification” questions before telling you things you already knew and tried. Occasionally, you eventually get your problem solved. But every time, precious minutes and hours of your life are sucked away, never to return. In the olden days, phone calls were the best way to solve customer problems. The alternative was writing a letter and waiting several days, or longer, to maybe receive a response, that MAYBE would actually be helpful or correct. Those days are past. People used to expect to have to talk to customer service. They expected regular issues, problems, etc, and that someone would have to fix it. And they expected to have to call on the phone to make it happen. Not anymore. If I buy something and it doesn’t work correctly, I am UPSET. I feel cheated. You sold me a thing that didn’t deliver on your promises! I need it fixed NOW. And I don’t want to pick up the phone and chat with the lowest ranking guy at your company about it. Prevent customer problems before they happen.Offer support via channels that respect people’s time.Email and live chat are both great options. Remember, customer service is what happens after you screw up. It’s you fixing your mistakes and making things right for the customers affected by them. Forcing me to pick up a phone and go through automation hell to fix a simple thing that shouldn’t have been broken in the first place is just fucking primitive. I write more about how businesses can get it right here.

Chat bots are becoming more sophisticated so that might impact call center’s business models as more companies rely on them directly from their website instead of outsourcing customer service to a 3rd party. You don’t actually speak with a representative (although that’s probably tech being worked on and around the corner too via a bot like an Alexa or Siri), though the bot is programmed to handle the unique requests a person can type and provide a response from the multitude of if this then that answers, kind of like a tree branch that splits off in directions and provides the output answers based on the input questions until the desired end result is arrived at.

Live chat bots, live chat lets a customer get in touch with support without leaving the web page. I myself would prefer to talk to someone on live chat when I am browsing a site on my laptop, instead of picking up the phone and dialing the number. Even on mobile if you don’t have to leave the browser I prefer live chat over calling. Chat bots which are constantly updated and have a lot of data to offer may take some load off call centers. Max 30% load off. But it is a big number if you consider the total. Initially more jobs for coders but in long run cheaper solution.

Social media! If all businesses started relying on social media for all customer interaction, call centers would be gone. Startups and SMEs are already doing it coz they can't afford a call centre; however, bigger companies like GE, and other are heavely present on social media. This answer could be very long, but to sum it up, social media is the new customer engagement platform. It is already impacting call centers.

Nothing. Humans are feeling and sensitive beings and are requesting many times special attention to find and accept a solution. Computers cannot provide that because they are machines that cannot feel anything. They can try to simulate feelings but no computer so far has managed to convince me. They're just bad at it. If we someday lose our ability to feel then the world is finally computers.
Humans working in call centres and driving Ubers are helping to create the data pool necessary for technology to take over. Yes.
